Moritz said:

I've looked at the linear algebra part of it and I feel like even that is in need of a quite significant cleanup: I think it is possible to unify bilinear_map, bilin_form and sesq_form into a single semibilin_map which has the former three as special cases. The definition could be essentially what is the definition of bilin_form but way more general (yesterday I generalized it to a bilinear map, but not with the ring homomorphism yet). the way that bilin_form is written makes it easy to extend it to a bounded bilinear form, I don't see how to do the same thing with the current definition of the bilinear map.

Is there any reason to use these over things like E ‚Üí‚Çó[R] F ‚Üí‚Çó[R] G?

@Moritz I agree, that whole part of the library needs a clean-up. I think we all know this, and have been put off because it's a big task! Here are some of the design considerations that have occured to me ... what do you think? (Tagging @Fr√©d√©ric Dupuis @Eric Wieser also):

  1. (you mentioned this one) do we try to unite R-bilinear maps M ‚Üí N ‚Üí P with R-bilinear forms M ‚Üí M ‚Üí R?

  2. do we try to make the theory parallel with R-multilinear maps Œ†(i : Œπ), M‚ÇÅ i ‚Üí M‚ÇÇ? (note: it is common in mathlib to have parallel developments of the 2-input and arbitrary-input version of something, like pi vs prod, sup vs Sup, etc; sometimes there is an effor to make these two developments exactly parallel, sometimes it's looser).

  3. how do we deal with semilinearity, and in particular with the interaction between semilinearity and noncommutativity? Note that currently sesq_form is effectively for a docs#star_ring R, requiring the map be R-linear in one argument and I : R ‚âÉ+* R·µí·µñ-semilinear in the other argument, so a full generalization would need to deal with multiple possible scalar rings (R, R·µí·µñat least, but why not more?). Or we could just give up on the attempt to deal with noncommutativity here.

  4. (maybe to be deferred to a future refactor) how does this interact with docs#inner_product_space? I think eventually it would be nice to have something like the integration library, where you can work with a particular measure if you specify it, or with some silent default measure if not -- so here there might in some cases be a silent default bilinear form, and sometimes an explicitly-specified one.
This topic was moved here from #new members > Bounded bilinear forms by Anne Baanen

I was also thinking about this because just yesterday I opened a PR (#10373) to allow semilinear versions of maps of type E ‚Üí‚Çó[R] F ‚Üí‚Çó[R] G, i.e. E ‚Üí‚Çõ‚Çó[œÉ] F ‚Üí‚Çõ‚Çó[œÅ] G, with [module R‚ÇÅ E], [module R‚ÇÇ F] and [module R‚ÇÉ G], and œÉ : R‚ÇÅ ‚Üí+* R‚ÇÉ, œÅ : R‚ÇÇ ‚Üí+* R‚ÇÉ. As far as I can tell, this should cover pretty much all cases of interest, so I was wondering if we should just use that systematically and deprecate bilin_form and sesq_form.

Interesting ... yes, it does seem to cover all cases of interest. It makes the parallel with multilinear maps Œ†(i : Œπ), M‚ÇÅ i ‚Üí M‚ÇÇ less direct, though. (Note that eventually we want semimultilinear maps, too, or at least I do! How do we do those?)

Heather Macbeth said:

Interesting ... yes, it does seem to cover all cases of interest. It makes the parallel with multilinear maps Œ†(i : Œπ), M‚ÇÅ i ‚Üí M‚ÇÇ less direct, though. (Note that eventually we want semimultilinear maps, too, or at least I do! How do we do those?)

We could semilinearize multilinear maps by replacing R with an indexed family of ring homs that all go to the same output ring.
But that doesn't work if (say) the output ring is sometimes R, sometimes R·µí·µñ
(For me, it would be a commutative ring, where this doesn't matter.)
Maybe we need an indexed family of ring homs, all of whose output rings have actions on M‚ÇÇ
with some compatibility condition like docs#smul_comm_class on these actions
What do you mean "sometimes"? The output space has to be a module over some ring -- which one is it?
Ah I see. Yes that could work.

Fr√©d√©ric Dupuis said:

What do you mean "sometimes"? The output space has to be a module over some ring -- which one is it?

Look at the current docs#sesq_form, which is a map M ‚Üí M ‚Üí R, where the R is considered as being both an R-module and an R·µí·µñ-module, so that a sesquilinear form is R-linear in the first argument and (I : R ‚âÉ+* R·µí·µñ)-sesquilinear in the second argument.
Ah I see. Yeah we would need some sort of compatibility condition on the actions on the output space.
Maybe even just having two unrelated module instances would suffice.
Yes ... with the assumption of compatibility added in where actually required.

Here's something that seems as general as I can make it, and which would admit an exact parallel for docs#multilinear_map:

import algebra.module.basic

variables (R‚ÇÅ R‚ÇÇ S‚ÇÅ S‚ÇÇ M‚ÇÅ M‚ÇÇ N : Type*)
variables [semiring R‚ÇÅ] [semiring R‚ÇÇ] [semiring S‚ÇÅ] [semiring S‚ÇÇ]
variables [add_comm_monoid M‚ÇÅ] [module R‚ÇÅ M‚ÇÅ]
variables [add_comm_monoid M‚ÇÇ] [module R‚ÇÇ M‚ÇÇ]
variables [add_comm_monoid N] [module S‚ÇÅ N] [module S‚ÇÇ N]
variables (œÉ‚ÇÅ : R‚ÇÅ ‚Üí+* S‚ÇÅ) (œÉ‚ÇÇ : R‚ÇÇ ‚Üí+* S‚ÇÇ)

structure bilinear_map :=
(bilin : M‚ÇÅ ‚Üí M‚ÇÇ ‚Üí N)
(bilin_add_left : ‚àÄ (x y : M‚ÇÅ) (z : M‚ÇÇ), bilin (x + y) z = bilin x z + bilin y z)
(bilin_smul_left : ‚àÄ (a : R‚ÇÅ) (x : M‚ÇÅ) (y : M‚ÇÇ), bilin (a ‚Ä¢ x) y = œÉ‚ÇÅ a ‚Ä¢ (bilin x y))
(bilin_add_right : ‚àÄ (x : M‚ÇÅ) (y z : M‚ÇÇ), bilin x (y + z) = bilin x y + bilin x z)
(bilin_smul_right : ‚àÄ (a : R‚ÇÇ) (x : M‚ÇÅ) (y : M‚ÇÇ), bilin x (a ‚Ä¢ y) = œÉ‚ÇÇ a ‚Ä¢ (bilin x y))
(with [smul_comm_class S‚ÇÅ S‚ÇÇ N] added presumably for certain theorems)

Do we actually need a structure for this? I was hoping to be able to get away with just E ‚Üí‚Çõ‚Çó[œÉ] F ‚Üí‚Çõ‚Çó[œÅ] G, and I guess now with œÉ : R‚ÇÅ ‚Üí+* R‚ÇÉ and œÅ : R‚ÇÇ ‚Üí+* S‚ÇÉ, where R‚ÇÉ and S‚ÇÉ both have actions on G.

The definition could be essentially what is the definition of bilin_form but way more general (yesterday I generalized it to a bilinear map, but not with the ring homomorphism yet). the way that bilin_form is written makes it easy to extend it to a bounded bilinear form, I don't see how to do the same thing with the current definition of the bilinear map.

Which is exactly what you want for a conjugate-linear form, as you can pass docs#star_ring_equiv : R ‚âÉ+* R·µê·µí·µñ as œÉ‚ÇÇ.
The question was about the case of bilinear forms, so that œÅ = œÉ = ring_hom.id R

def semibilin_map (R : Type*) (R‚ÇÇ : Type*) (S : Type*) (S‚ÇÇ : Type*)
  [semiring R] [semiring R‚ÇÇ] [semiring S] [semiring S‚ÇÇ]

  [module R M] [module R N] [module R P] [smul_comm_class R R P]

While the current docs#bilin_form only requires semiring R, it looks like the axioms pretty much force you to have R be commutative

They're enough to show that (a * b) * self.bilin x y = (b * a) * self.bilin x y for all a, b, x, y, which is only a few steps away from a * b = b * a. I guess you can happily use the 0 form in the noncommutative setting, but it's pretty useless.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sesquilinear_form#Over_a_division_ring

is there a possibility to do type-aliases in lean? so that we could write bilinear_form R M and it gets internally resolved to semibilin_map R R R R M M R (ring_hom.id R) (ring_hom.id R)

Unfortunately not; you can define type-aliases but they don't unfold everywhere so to speak, so are not completely silent.

A very common workaround in mathlib is notation, which is completely silent. So for the case of linear/conjugate-linear/semilinear maps we have separate notations for the concepts, even though the first two are special cases of the last.

notation M ` ‚Üí‚Çõ‚Çó[`:25 œÉ:25 `] `:0 M‚ÇÇ:0 := linear_map œÉ M M‚ÇÇ
notation M ` ‚Üí‚Çó[`:25 R:25 `] `:0 M‚ÇÇ:0 := linear_map (ring_hom.id R) M M‚ÇÇ
notation M ` ‚Üí‚Çó‚ãÜ[`:25 R:25 `] `:0 M‚ÇÇ:0 := linear_map (@star_ring_aut R _ _ : R ‚Üí+* R) M M‚ÇÇ

This provides for

f : M ‚Üí‚Çõ‚Çó[œÉ] M‚ÇÇ
f : M ‚Üí‚Çó[R] M‚ÇÇ
f : M ‚Üí‚Çó‚ãÜ[R] M‚ÇÇ

semilinear, linear, conjugate-linear in that order.

We might like to introduce some notation for bilinear and sesquilinear forms; then they could be silent special cases of semibilinear forms.

If the only reason we want those types to exist is to enable dot notation, what's wrong with putting the lemmas we want in the linear_map and continuous_linear_map namespaces, as is done in bilinear_map.lean?
